Call me if you need me before then." Padme nodded to him, the slightest trace of a frown furrowing her brow. Obi-Wan walked out, still ignoring Anakin, heading back to the speeder. As soon as he started up the engine, Padme whirled on Anakin, the frown in full effect on her brow. "What happened between you two? He won't tell me." Anakin winced. "We... talked. He's still hurt, from before. And then yesterday, he wouldn't believe me when I said I loved him. So I kissed him. And now..." He spread his hands in defeat. Padme sighed, squeezing Anakin's arm. "Anakin... we need to talk. But where are Luke and Leia? He said he'd left them with you." "They're napping. They spilled juice, and I put them to bed. They won't be up for another hour or so." She nodded and led him over to the couch. She sat down, bunching up her heavy skirts so they'd lie flat. When Anakin sat beside her, she took his hand in hers, stroking his fingers. "Anakin, he said you went into shock. Like you used to... after..." She sounded more than worried, she sounded afraid. Anakin stared at their intertwined hands before looking at Padme. "It's okay. It was just that he was telling me how hurt he was. It brought everything back. Everything he said was true, and I felt so lost and empty..." "Oh, Anakin." She stroked his cheek, biting her bottom lip. "He's spent these past four years focusing on you and the Jedi and the twins, but has left no time for himself. He'll always be hurt. You can't change that, but you can move past that. If he didn't love you so much, he wouldn't have agreed to help you." "I didn't see it before. He should have told me. He shouldn't be so contained." There was genuine concern in Anakin's voice. The degree of control and selflessness Obi-Wan displayed sometimes worried him. It couldn't be good for Obi-Wan to keep everything inside like that. "You know how he is. He's devoted his whole life to you, even now." Padme dropped her hand, leaning back against the cushions of the couch as she studied Anakin's face. "Why did you kiss him?" she asked slowly. "Because he thought I didn't love him. He thought I only loved you. I was trying to change his mind." Anakin drew in a deep breath, hoping Padme still understood. "I love you both." Padme already knew this, but Anakin felt it bore repeating. "I know, but..." Padme licked her lips, staring out of the open window. A breeze drifted through, making the elaborate braids on top of her head tremble. "Loving two people. Anakin, it's a hard idea for most people to live with. Even for me." Anakin took her in his arms again, wanting to reassure her of how much he appreciated her for staying with him, much less loving him. "Nothing will make me love you less. I promise." She wrapped her arms around him, burying her face in his shoulder. "I know. We've always shared you, I suppose, though I don't think he consciously realized that. But even if Obi-Wan realizes you belong with him as much as me, that might not fix anything. Obi-Wan has his own demons to wrestle with." "I wish I knew how to help him." Anakin felt like such a drain of everyone else. He wanted to help, but didn't know where to start. He didn't even know if trying to convince Obi-Wan of his feelings would help, but maybe that was a start. "I don't know, Anakin. Obi-Wan can take care of himself. I worry about you. You shouldn't be going into shock like this. I thought we were past this." "It was just once. I'm fine now, I promise." He didn't want Padme to worry about him. She had more important things to worry about."It's not going to happen again." Padme pulled back, her expression dead serious. "Anakin, Luke and Leia depend on you, now." Her voice was as hard as durasteel. "I love you, you know that, but if you endanger the lives of my children, you'll never see them again. We're trusting you. I know it's been hard for you, but I want you to remember who you are -- the good man I married seven years ago on Naboo." Anakin's heart stopped. He couldn't imagine living without Luke and Leia. He had come back from the dark side for them, and they were his reason for living. "I will never hurt our children. I will die before I let anything happen to them. Even if that means hurting myself rather than letting my anger get the best of me." Padme bent forward, resting her forehead against his, looking into his eyes. "I believe you. Don't go where I can't follow again," she whispered. "Never again, love." Anakin sealed the promise with a kiss and rested his cheek against her braided hair, wondering if he could ever make Obi-Wan believe in him as much as Padme did. Continued in Part Three!

This part is a little over 3000 words. ==> All parts can be read here! Anakin had often heard that good intentions paved the road to hell, but no one had any answers on what paved the road back. He meditated every day, trying to find the answer in the Force instead. Fear had driven Anakin to the dark side, and even now that he had turned away from it, fear still haunted him. It kept him awake at night, lying on a wide marriage bed that was lonely more often than not, and even when he slept, dreams of his sins plagued him. What little peace he found was when he was with the people he loved, but when they weren't there, he was afraid. Afraid of himself. Afraid of what he'd done. Afraid he'd never be forgiven. Shrieks and laughter startled Anakin out of his meditations. He let his consciousness drift back into his body, where he sat on a mat inside his small house on the outskirts of the Jedi settlement on Agran. He tried to drain as much of his negative emotions as he could into the Force. He listened to the noises outside, finally recognizing Luke and Leia's high-pitched voices. He knew Obi-Wan had to be with them. Obi-Wan was always with them when they came to visit, supervising to make sure that nothing happened. Anakin had stopped resenting Obi-Wan for that long ago; after all that had happened, it was enough he got to see Luke and Leia at all when Padme wasn't there to watch over him. The dark time that had followed the twins' birth four years ago blurred in Anakin's memory, but he remembered enough to appreciate the precautions that Obi-Wan and Yoda were taking with him. In fear for Padme's life, he had sworn his allegiance to Palpatine and destroyed the Jedi Temple. On Mustafar, he had defeated Obi-Wan, slicing off the older man's right arm. Obi-Wan had cried out in pain a moment before Anakin knocked him unconscious and left him on the blackened shores of Mustafar. Anakin had run back to find his wife, using the dark side to keep her alive while she'd given birth to their babies. In the months that had followed, he had done Palpatine's bidding, biding his time until Padme was ready to become Empress. Things had turned out nothing like he'd expected. In the end, when Palpatine had threatened his children, Anakin had killed him and turned away from the dark side. Anakin had emerged from the battle shattered. Physically, he was unscathed, but mentally, he was lost. He was neither Jedi nor Sith, not dark or light. All the definitions that had held him together were gone. He had been able to care for himself and his family, even recognize Padme and Obi-Wan, but anything beyond that had overwhelmed him. His entire self had been emptied. Now, Anakin was recovering, finding pieces of himself along the way. The galaxy was healing, with Padme reforming the Senate and Obi-Wan and Yoda rebuilding the Jedi. Agran had been chosen as the retreat where the Jedi could recover, and Anakin had been brought along so that Obi-Wan and Yoda could continue the therapy they had begun with him. Padme had sent the twins along, knowing how much good they did Anakin, wishing to keep them away from the political maelstrom she dealt with. Obi-Wan and Yoda trained them as Jedi, but it was informal training, as Yoda still contemplated how the Jedi should adjust to the changes in the galaxy. Anakin came to his feet, leaving his tiny meditation room and entering the crowded sitting room full of the Naboo wicker furniture Padme had insisted putting it. He could hear Obi-Wan's voice, even though muffled through the wooden door. Anakin flung the door open in excitement. Obi-Wan stood just outside, hand raised to knock. He froze when he saw Anakin, and his smile faded, as if someone had shut a door on his face. Beside him, Leia held her shoes in her hands, white sand clinging to her tiny feet and pale legs as she pointed at the long beach several meters to the side of Anakin's small house. Luke sat on the step, ripping his own shoes off. He turned when Anakin opened the door, the only one to smile. The twins loved playing in the warm waters of Agran. "Hello, Anakin," said Obi-Wan in the cool, unfamiliar tone he used around Anakin now. "Your children wanted to know if they could go play in the water today." He gestured at the beach, the tide spraying onto the shore as he spoke. Agran was an idyllic, moderate planet filled with shallow oceans, flat grasslands, and deciduous forests -- perfectly resonating in the light side of the Force. Anakin had no doubt that was why Obi-Wan and Yoda had chosen it as the Jedi Order's new home. The planet itself had a healing nature to it. "Of course they can," Anakin said, feeling the twinge that always accompanied remembering that Obi-Wan no longer fully trusted him. He didn't blame Obi-Wan, of course, but it still hurt to see him so distant. He smiled at Luke and Leia. "Go on. I'm right behind you." He started to take off his boots, propping himself up in the doorway. "Thank you, Father," said Leia primly, eyeing Anakin for a moment. There was so much of Padme in her face and her intricately coiled brunette hair that it made Anakin's heart ache for his beloved wife, who wouldn't be able to return for at least another month. There had been another flare-up in the Senate, and she'd left again to take care of it. She was determined to see peace restored to the galaxy. Anakin couldn't blame her for the desire, since he'd been one of the reasons she had to work so hard to fix everything. His stomach twisted with guilt, and he looked away from Leia. Like Obi-Wan, she had a way of reminding him of his mistakes without even having to say anything. Luke finished peeling off his shoes and grabbed Anakin's hand, his elfin face lit up with a bright smile. "Don't take too long, Daddy," he said. "Ben made us kiri sandwiches, and he cut the crusts off, too." Luke squeezed Anakin's hand, the Force gently flowing from his fingertips, sending a soothing sensation through Anakin's body. After a moment, Luke turned and followed his sister to the water, both shrieking as they stripped down to their bathing suits and dived into the ocean. Obi-Wan still looked painfully neutral and bland. The smile he gave Anakin never reached his eyes. "Your supplies should be arriving by droid transport within the hour. Until then, I brought Luke's favorite sandwiches. He wouldn't leave me in peace unless I promised to make them this morning." He rolled his shoulder and patted a large bag he carried, presumably full of food. Anakin's gaze was drawn to Obi-Wan's right hand, remembering how he'd brought it and Obi-Wan's lightsaber before Palpatine, mistakenly thinking Obi-Wan would leave him alone. Anakin clenched his own right hand, which he still wore a black glove over, finding it ironic that he and Obi-Wan were a matched set now. "Are you coming?" asked Obi-Wan. He flexed his cybernetic hand. Though he left the skin covering on, he still wore a brown glove over it. Anakin knew Obi-Wan hated his mechanical hand; he'd always hated Anakin's. "Yes," Anakin said, rolling up his pants. He followed Obi-Wan down to the beach, murmuring an apology so quietly it was possible that only the wind heard it. He had thought to protect Obi-Wan by cutting off his arm, thinking he'd ensured that Obi-Wan wouldn't have pursued him, but it had backfired like nearly everything he had done in Palpatine's service. The sand was warm under Anakin's bare feet, and he was reminded of Tatooine for a moment. He looked out at the horizon, almost surprised to see one sun hanging over an ocean instead of two perched over a desert. Obi-Wan laid out a large blue blanket and sat on it, putting the bag down. He kept a watchful eye on Luke and Leia as they splashed each other, laughing and babbling the strange language they'd invented for themselves. Anakin felt another twist, this one not so familiar. Obi-Wan had never watched him so carefully when he'd been a boy. Anakin felt something being shoved in his hand, surprised to realize Obi-Wan had opened a satchel and was handing him a blue kiri sandwich. Obi-Wan looked away when Anakin stared into his face, the wind gently ruffling his wheat-colored hair. It had gotten long again. "I talked to Padme this morning when she called for the twins," he said, his voice as fluid as the blue-green ocean spread out before them. "The Senate is quieting down, so she may be back here within a month. She said to tell you hello, and that she would contact you tomorrow. She's worried you're not eating enough." Anakin smiled slightly. Padme was always worried about him for one reason or another. Anakin appreciated it, as he appreciated everything about Padme. She had been even more hurt by him than Obi-Wan, and yet, she stayed with him. He was thankful every moment for that, and made sure she was aware of it. It was her quiet strength that had started to heal him, and it was her faith that gave him the will to recover. She was sure he was a good person even when he himself doubted it. "I'll be looking forward to her call," Anakin said. He took a bit of the sandwich. "You did tell her I was eating, right?" Obi-Wan stared at the uneaten sandwich in his own hand. "I told her that as far as I knew, you were. She... seemed upset with me for not keeping a closer eye on you." A bit of sand blew across his face with the wind, and he brushed it off his cheek, as one might brush away a tear. Anakin sat down on the blanket, but continued to watch the twins play in the water. "I wish you would come visit more." Anakin missed Obi-Wan and didn't know how to begin repairing what he had so foolishly destroyed. He didn't even know how to ask. "I thought you wouldn't want me to. Not unless I was bringing your children or Padme out here." Anakin swallowed with difficulty. Where had Obi-Wan gotten that idea? "No, I want you to. I just didn't want to force you to." Anakin would never make Obi-Wan or anyone else do something they didn't want ever again. "You have a wife, two children... a family. Master Yoda is allowing it because he says the Jedi should change, but I don't see how there's room for anything or anyone else." Anakin risked a glance at Obi-Wan, his heart breaking at the thought that Obi-Wan didn't see his place in Anakin's life. "You were my friend," he said softly. "I miss you." Obi-Wan seemed old and sad when he met Anakin's gaze. "I miss you, too. But I'm not sure if you're the same person. And I can't decide if that's an improvement or not." "I..." Anakin didn't how to respond. He broke eye contact, staring at the fine white sand at his feet instead. "I don't know if I'm the same person. But I'm trying to be a better person." "I know you are," whispered Obi-Wan, his gloved fingers brushing along Anakin's arm. His lips parted as if to speak again, but Luke and Leia suddenly appeared, flinging their wet bodies down on the blanket between Anakin and Obi-Wan, still giggling. "Can I have a sandwich now, Ben?" asked Luke. He and Leia had been unable to pronounce Obi-Wan when they'd started talking, and their pet name for him had stuck. Anakin was surprised Obi-Wan hadn't talked the twins out of it yet, but he supposed Obi-Wan was changing, too. Obi-Wan passed sandwiches out to both Luke and Leia. He caught Anakin's eye and signaled "later" with a hooked finger and thumb along his jaw line, using the hand signals he and Anakin had developed for each other during the Clone Wars. It seemed appropriate as Luke and Leia babbled in their private jibberish, ripping huge bites of sandwiches off between nonsense words. Anakin had thought their language strange, until Padme had told him twins often made up their own language; it made them feel special and close. Anakin certainly couldn't begrudge his children that. The code he and Obi-Wan had used to communicate with had always made him feel the same. Obi-Wan's quiet words and gentle touch eased the gaping emptiness that haunted Anakin just the slightest bit. He wanted to connect with Obi-Wan like he had once, and they were just a little closer to that goal. He rubbed his eyebrow in agreement with Obi-Wan's silent signal, and turned to the twins. "Smaller bites! Your mother would be upset if she saw you eating like that." Luke and Leia giggled and slowed down, both now chatting to Anakin, telling him about how Master Yoda had let them play with their first training sabers the other day and how much fun they were having with the new children brought to Agran and what few Jedi had survived Order 66. Obi-Wan kept silent, letting Anakin spend time with his children. When the droid transport arrived with Anakin's supplies, Obi-Wan left them alone to unload them. When the sun dipped low into the cerulean sky, Obi-Wan appeared and ushered them all back to Anakin's house. He insisted the twins take a bath, forcing them into dry clothing stored in their closets in their room. They did not sleep at Anakin's house unless Padme was there with them. Anakin made a quick dinner of souri steaks and pinan, which was quickly devoured by the four of them. The twins quickly got tired after that, and Obi-Wan put them in their small beds to Anakin's surprise, rather than quickly ushering them back to the main compound. Anakin kissed them good night, grateful to have them there with them. They brought him peace, even fiery little Leia After they fell asleep, Anakin followed Obi-Wan to the peach-walled sitting room. The smell of the ocean drifted in through an open window, and a gentle breeze sent the curtain fluttering. Though he'd spent his formative years on a desert planet, the sounds of the ocean comforted Anakin, reminding him of his mother for some reason. Obi-Wan said nothing shouldered his bag, glancing thoughtfully back at Anakin. There was a bit more gray in his beard, startling Anakin as it gleamed in the dim overhead lighting. "I'm going to let them stay here with you," Obi-Wan finally said. Anakin froze in shock. Obi-Wan and Yoda had always worried that he might have relapsed and hurt the children. Not that he would; he had killed Palpatine to protect them, and he would never let anything happen to them, even if the danger was from himself. "Thank you," Anakin said quietly. "They'll be fine here. You can come visit them any time." Obi-Wan still looked thoughtful, but hesitant. His eyes were very intent; they seemed bluer than Anakin remembered. "I'll be back at the end of the week. I'm trusting you to take care of them." He put a slight emphasis on the word "trust". "I will. I promise." Anakin had never been more serious in his life. He didn't want to disappoint Obi-Wan again. He had failed Obi-Wan enough for one lifetime already. Obi-Wan nodded and turned to leave. His beard twitched, and it took Anakin a moment to realize it was because he was working his jaw. Then Obi-Wan drew his hood up, hiding his face under the dark brown cloth. Anakin hesitated, but touched Obi-Wan's arm. "Do you have to leave right now?" Obi-Wan glanced down at his hand, considering it for a long moment before speaking. "No." Anakin swallowed. "We were talking earlier..." Obi-Wan met his gaze, peering out from under his hood. "We were. I don't know what to say to you anymore, Anakin. The whole time I thought you were with me, there was a part of you with Padme. I won't pretend I didn't know something was going on, but I never thought it was something like this." He looked away. "I suppose I was blind." "I loved you as much as I loved Padme." The truth was as simple as that. "When I was with her, there was a part of me with you." Obi-Wan held up his gloved hand. His smile was thin as a circuit wire. "I find that a little hard to believe, given what happened on Mustafar." Anakin winced. "You weren't supposed to follow me. You were supposed to give up and be safe. I needed to make it look like you died, so you could be safe." Anakin didn't know if Obi-Wan would understand, but it was the only explanation he had. Obi-Wan dropped his hand, his expression closing. "Don't insult me or our friendship by trying to paint a pretty coat over what you did, Anakin." For the first time since Mustafar, he sounded angry. Anakin winced again. "I'm sorry. I know what I did. But that was why. I wanted you safe." "Is that how you justify your actions? You didn't care whether I lived or died. I was no longer important, because I was your enemy. If you're going to continue to lie, then I'm leaving." Obi-Wan turned away again, reaching for the doorknob. "Dammit, if I had wanted to kill you, I would have!" Anakin reached for him, his eyes stinging. "Please believe me." Obi-Wan looked up at the ceiling, his hood falling back from his handsome face. "How could you, Anakin? I don't care what you did to me, but the younglings..." His tone hardened. "How could you ever justify the life of one woman for all those people you killed? For betraying the Jedi? For betraying me?" When he finally looked at Anakin, he wore the look of hurt he'd worn on Mustafar. "I loved you, Anakin. You were my brother." Anakin didn't reply. He couldn't reply. Everything Obi-Wan was saying was true, and there was nothing Anakin could do about it. He had failed at everything he tried, and he had brought the galaxy down with him. Why Obi-Wan and Yoda even bothered to heal him was beyond him. Nothing mattered. He didn't realize he had sunk to the floor until he felt the scratch of the rug under his cheek and a sharp pain in his arm. Continued in Part Two!
